case_name: Venugopala Varma Rajah v. Agricultural Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 266 of 1969 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 266 of 1969. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated August 16, 1967 of Kerala High Court in Income-tax Referred Case No. 44 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 16, 1967 of the Kerala High Court in Income-tax Referred Case No. 44 of 1966.

facts.text: Appellant Venugopala Varma Rajah is the present Rajah of the Vengunad Swaroopan in Palghat District, Kerala State and Karnavan of his Tarwad.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Venugopala Varma Rajah is the present Rajah of the Vengunad Swaroopan in Palghat District, Kerala State. He is the Karnavan of his Tarwad.

facts.text: Predecessor of appellant as Karnavan submitted return for assessment year 1959-60 under Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Act showing gross income Rs. 1,21,912/- and net income Rs. 84,065/60 P.

anchor.surface_text: The predecessor of the appellant, as the then Kamavan of the family, submitted the return for the assessment year 1959-60 under the Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Act  which will hereinafter be referred to as the Act  showing a gross income of Rs. 1,21,912/- and a net income of Rs. 84,065/60 P.

facts.text: Income in return represented income from properties held under family Karar dated May 29, 1909.

anchor.surface_text: That represented the income from the properties held by him under the family Karar dated May 29, 1909.

facts.text: Agricultural Income-tax Officer included income of properties put in possession of junior members under 1909 Karar, overruling assessee's objection; net income Rs. 2,32,957/-, tax Rs. 1,30,672/35 P.

anchor.surface_text: The. Agricultural Income-tax Officer overruling the objection of the assessee included in the income returned, the income of the properties which had been put in possession of the junior members of the family under the aforementioned Karar of 1909. The net income so companyputed was Rs. 2,32,957/- and a tax of Rs. 1,30,672/35 P. was imposed.

facts.text: Appellate Authority excluded income of properties allotted to Rani Group but sustained addition of income of properties allotted to male members.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the Appellate Authority excluded from the taxable income the income of the properties allotted to the Rani Group but sustained the addition of the income of the properties allotted for the enjoyment of the male members.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal rejected assessee's contention and dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the order of the Appellate Authority, the assessee took up the matter in second appeal to the Appellate Tribunal of the Agricultural Income-tax. The Tribunal rejected the companytention of the assessee and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Tribunal stated case under s. 60(1) of the Act to High Court on three questions of law.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter at the instance of the assessee, it stated a case under s. 60 1  of the Act and submitted to the High Court for its opinion three questions of law namely

facts.text: Kerala High Court by judgment dated August 16, 1967 answered Questions 1 and 2 against assessee, did not answer Question 3.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its judgment dated August 16, 1967 answered Question Nos. 1 and 2 against the assessee. It did number answer the third question as it was of the view that answer to that question was unnecessary in view of its findings on Questions Nos. 1 and 2.

facts.text: Appeal brought by certificate to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter this appeal was brought by certificate.

facts.text: Assessee is H.U.F. of which appellant was Karnavan at relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee in this case is the H.U.F. of which the appellant was the Kamavan at the relevant time.

facts.text: Karar of 1909 entered by all 12 living members of the family.

anchor.surface_text: To the Karar in question all the then living members   12 in number  of the family were parties.

facts.text: Family is one of premier land holding families in Malabar with agricultural properties in various places.

anchor.surface_text: The family of the assessee appears to have been one of the premier land holding families in Malabar. It appears to have had agricultural properties in various places.

facts.text: Properties in A Schedule set apart for maintenance, education etc. of female and male members in Kalari Kovilagom (Rani Group).

anchor.surface_text: The properties mentioned in A Sch. to the Karar were set apart for the maintenance, education and other expenses of the female and male members residing in Kalari Kovilagom which is otherwise known as Rani Group.

facts.text: Karnavan to perform marriage ceremonies of female members and meet expenses from A Sch. properties.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Karar, Karnavan of the Tarwad was to perform the marriage ceremonies of the female members of the Tarwad in accordance with the prevailing companyditions and to meet 1004 the expenses thereof.

facts.text: Party No. 2 given 7,000 paras paddy annually from B Sch. properties yielding 3,500 paras.

anchor.surface_text: Party No. 2, the second senior most member in the family was to be given 7,000 paras of paddy annually for his maintenance and for this purpose paddy lands yielding 3,500 paras of paddy shown in B Sch. were made over to his possession

facts.text: C Sch. properties yielding 4,750 paras allotted to Party No. 3 for maintenance.

anchor.surface_text: C Sch. properties yielding an income of 4,750 paras of paddy were allotted for the enjoyment of Party No. 3. He was required to maintain himself from out of their income.

facts.text: D Sch. properties set apart for maintenance of Party No. 4.

anchor.surface_text: Properties shown in D Sch. were set apart for the mainte- nance of Party No. 4.

facts.text: Land-revenue of B, C, D Sch. properties paid by Karnavan.

anchor.surface_text: The land-revenue of B, C and D Sch. properties was required to be paid by the Karnavan of the tarwad.

facts.text: On death of Party No. 2 or becoming Karnavan, Party No. 3 takes B Sch., Party No. 4 takes C Sch.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of Party No. 2 or on his becoming Karnavan of the family, Party No. 3 was to take over the properties allotted for the maintenance of Party No. 2 and Party No. 4 was to take over the properties for the maintenance of Party No. 3.

facts.text: Karar prohibits alienation or encumbrance of allotted properties; Karnavan can resume if contravened.

anchor.surface_text: The Karar prohibited the persons who were in possession of the properties allotted for their enjoyment from alienating or encumbering those properties, and if in companytravention of those terms, they alienated any of those properties, the Karnavan was entitled to resume the properties treating the alienation as void.

facts.text: Male members over 21 to leave Kalari; Karnavan to arrange maintenance.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 6 of the Karar provided that all the male members living in the Kalari, on companypleting the age of 21 should leave the Kalari and thereafter the Kamavan should make arrangements for their maintenance.

facts.text: Parties Nos. 2,3,4 have died.

anchor.surface_text: all of whom, we were told have died.

facts.text: Court finds joint status not disrupted; arrangement for maintenance only, properties remain family properties.

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the various clauses in the Karar, it is obvious that the joint status of the parties was number disrupted. The arrangement made in the Karar was only an arrangement for providing maintenance. No party was given any absolute right in any portion of the family properties.
Thereafter at the instance of the assessee, it stated a case under s. 60(1) of the Act and submitted to the High Court for its opinion three questions of law namely

anchor.surface_text: Section 9 of the Act provides 9(1) In computing the total agricultural income of an assessee all agricultural income arising to any person by virtue of a settlement or disposition, whether revocable or not, and whether effected before or after the commencement of this Act, from asset remaining the property of the settlor or disponer shall be deemed to be the agricultural income of the settlor or disponer

anchor.surface_text: Section 9(1) of the Act is similar to s. 16(1)(c) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. The courts have laid down the test that if the income in dispute is considered as having been applied to discharge an obligation of the assessee, the same is liable to be included in the assessable income of the assessee but if on the other hand the same had been diverted by an overriding charge, then it is not liable to be included

arguments.claim: Joint status of the parties not disrupted by Karar; arrangement only for providing maintenance; no absolute right given; properties remain family properties

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the various clauses in the Karar, it is obvious that the joint status of the parties was not disrupted. The arrangement made in the Karar was only an arrangement for providing maintenance. No party was given any absolute right in any portion of the family properties.

arguments.claim: Arrangement under Karar is revocable if substantial change in family circumstances

anchor.surface_text: In the very nature of things, the arrangement made under that Karar must be held to be one which is revocable if there is any substantial change in the circumstances of the family.

anchor.surface_text: The income is the income of the family. It reached the hands of the family as soon as it reached the hands of any of the members of the family who were entitled to receive it on behalf of the family.

arguments.claim: Makanji Lalji case: maintenance to widow from HUF not deductible

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Makanji Lalji , wherein Beaumont C.J., speaking for the court held that in computing the income of the H.U.F. for purposes of income-tax, moneys paid to the widow... cannot be deducted...

holdings.text: The joint status of the parties was not disrupted. The arrangement made in the Karar was only an arrangement for providing maintenance. No party was given any absolute right in any portion of the family properties. The properties mentioned in the Karar continued to be the properties of the family.

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the various clauses in the Karar, it is obvious that the joint status of the parties was not disrupted. The arrangement made in the Karar was only an arrangement for providing maintenance. No party was given any absolute right in any portion of the family properties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of Karar clauses shows no partition or absolute rights granted; only maintenance provision; properties revertible; Karnavan retains key responsibilities.

holdings.text: The arrangement made under that Karar must be held to be one which is revocable if there is any substantial change in the circumstances of the family.

anchor.surface_text: Under these circumstances, it is not possible to hold that Karar in question embodied an irrevocable settlement. In the very nature of things, the arrangement made under that Karar must be held to be one which is revocable if there is any substantial change in the circumstances of the family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Karar silent on increased family size or post-death devolution; Karnavan can resume properties; not permanent or irrevocable settlement.

holdings.text: The properties allotted for the enjoyment of the various members of the family under the Karar continued to be the properties of the family.

anchor.surface_text: For our present purpose it is sufficient if we hold that the properties allotted for the enjoyment of the various members of the family under the Karar continued to be the properties of the family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No division by Thavazhies; prohibition on alienation; resumption power; retention of land revenue payment by Karnavan.

holdings.text: In view of s. 9(1) of the Act in computing the total agricultural income of the H.U.F., all agricultural income arising from the assets remaining the property of the family should be deemed to be the agricultural income of the family.

anchor.surface_text: In view of s. 9(1) of the Act in computing the total agricultural income of the H.U.F., all agricultural income arising from the assets remaining the property of the family should be deemed to be the agricultural income of the family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.9(1) text to facts where assets remain family property post-Karar.

holdings.text: If we apply this test to the facts of the present case, it is clear that the income in dispute continued to be the income of the family. It was merely applied to discharge an obligation of the family namely the obligation to maintain the junior members of the family.

anchor.surface_text: If we apply this test to the facts of the present case, it is clear that the income in dispute continued to be the income of the family. It was merely applied to discharge an obligation of the family namely the obligation to maintain the junior members of the family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Test from precedents: diversion by overriding charge vs application to obligation; here latter as maintenance duty of family.

holdings.text: The income is the income of the family. It reached the hands of the family as soon as it reached the hands of any of the members of the family who were entitled to receive it on behalf of the family.

anchor.surface_text: The income is the income of the family. It reached the hands of the family as soon as it reached the hands of any of the members of the family who were entitled to receive it on behalf of the family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal receipt by family when members receive on behalf; not requiring physical receipt by Karnavan; distinguishes physical from legal concept.

holdings.text: A Hindu Undivided Family is a person within the meaning of s.2(m) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: A Hindu Undivided Family is a person within the, meaning of s.2(m) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definition application to Tarwad as HUF.

precedents.citation: Raja Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: Raja Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal 1 . The, assessee therein succeeded to the family ancestral estate on the death of his father. Subsequently his step-mother brought a suit for maintenance against him in which a companysent decree was made directing the assessee to make a monthly payment of a fixed sum to his step-mother and declaring that the maintenance was a charge on the ancestral estate in the hands of the assessee.

precedents.case_name: Raja Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Sums paid under a court decree charging the estate with maintenance are diverted by overriding title before becoming the assessee's income
precedents.cited_holding: the decree of the court by charging the appellants whole resources with a specific payment to his step-mother had to that extent diverted his income from him and had directed it to his step-mother [...] it was rather the allocation of a sum out of his revenue before it became income in his hands

precedents.citation: P. C. Mullick and anr. Executors v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: P. C. Mullick and anr. Executors v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal 1 . Therein a testator had by his will appointed the appellants his executors and had directed them to pay Rs. 10,000/- out of the income of his property on the occasion of his addya sradh for expenses in connection therewith to the person who was entitled to perform the sradh.

precedents.case_name: P. C. Mullick and anr. Executors v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Payments made out of income received to discharge an obligation are an application of income, not a diversion
precedents.cited_holding: it was not a case in which a portion of the income was by an overriding title diverted [...] but a case in which the executors having received the whole income apply a portion of it in a particular way

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Sitaldas Tirathdas 3

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Sitaldas Tirathdas 3 . Therein the assessee Sitaldas Tirathdas of Bombay had many sources of income, chief among them being property, stocks and shares, bank deposits and share in a firm known as M s. Sitaldas Tirathdas.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Sitaldas Tirathdas
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between diversion of income by overriding obligation before it reaches the assessee and application of income after receipt to discharge obligation
precedents.cited_holding: the true test is whether the amount sought to be deducted, in truth, never reached the assessee as his income. [...] Where by the obligation income is diverted before it reaches the assessee, it is deductible, but where the income is required to be applied to discharge an obligation after such income reaches the assessee, the same consequence, in law, does not follow

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Makanji Lalji 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Makanji Lalji 1 , wherein Beaumont C.J., speaking for the court held that in computing the income of the H.U.F. for purposes of income-tax, moneys paid to the widow of a deceased coparcener of the- family as maintenance and residence allowance cannot be deducted, even though the amount of such allowance has been fixed by a decree of the Court and has be en made a charge on properties belonging to the family.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Makanji Lalji
precedents.cited_proposition: Maintenance payments to widow of deceased coparcener from HUF income cannot be deducted even if fixed by decree and charged on family properties
precedents.cited_holding: in computing the income of the H.U.F. for purposes of income-tax, moneys paid to the widow of a deceased coparcener of the family as maintenance and residence allowance cannot be deducted, even though the amount of such allowance has been fixed by a decree of the Court and has been made a charge on properties belonging to the family

anchor.surface_text: If we apply this test to the facts of the present case, it is clear that the income in dispute continued to be the income of the family. It was merely applied to discharge an obligation of the family namely the obligation to maintain the junior members of the family. At first sight some of the decided cases on the subject appear to speak in conflicting voices.

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the various clauses in the Karar, it is obvious that the joint status of the parties was not disrupted. The arrangement made in the Karar was only an arrangement for providing maintenance. No party was given any absolute right in any portion of the family properties.

anchor.surface_text: Under these circumstances, it is not possible to hold that Karar in question embodied an irrevocable settlement. In the very nature of things, the arrangement made under that Karar must be held to be one which is revocable if there is any substantial change in the circumstances of the family.

If we apply this test to the facts of the present case, it is clear that the income in dispute continued to be the income of the family. It was merely applied to discharge an obligation of the family namely the obligation to maintain the junior members of the family. At first sight some of the decided cases on the subject appear to speak in conflicting voices.

anchor.surface_text: For our present purpose it is sufficient if we hold that the properties allotted for the enjoyment of the various members of the family under the Karar continued to be the properties of the family.

If we apply this test to the facts of the present case, it is clear that the income in dispute continued to be the income of the family. It was merely applied to discharge an obligation of the family namely the obligation to maintain the junior members of the family. At first sight some of the decided cases on the subject appear to speak in conflicting voices.

In view of s. 9(1) of the Act in computing the total agricultural income of the H.U.F., all agricultural income arising from the assets remaining the property of the family should be deemed to be the agricultural income of the family.

If we apply this test to the facts of the present case, it is clear that the income in dispute continued to be the income of the family. It was merely applied to discharge an obligation of the family namely the obligation to maintain the junior members of the family. At first sight some of the decided cases on the subject appear to speak in conflicting voices.
